p: Elevated cardiac biomarkers have been identified in COVID-19 patients, especially in those with severe conditions. Of note, recent case reports highlighted cardiac involvement as a complication associated with COVID-19, even without respiratory symptoms [ 30, 52]. Myocardial injury, defined as elevated cardiac biomarkers, was found in five of the first 41 patients (12%) with COVID-19 in Wuhan, which mainly manifested as an increase in high-sensitivity cardiac troponin I (hs-cTnI) levels (>28 pg/mL) [ 8]. In this study, the incidence was significantly higher in patients with ICU care than those without (31% vs. 4%, p = 0.017).
